Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 46496-001  
Capacity Development Technical Assistance (CDTA) 
August 2013 
 
 
 
Republic of the Union of Myanmar: Transformation 
of Urban Management 
(Financed by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction) 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 15 August 2013)

$1.00  =  MK973.57

  ALOS  –  Advanced Land Observing Satellite

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Capacity development technical assistance (CDTA) 
Targeting classification  –  General intervention 
Sector (subsectors)  –  Water supply and other municipal infrastructure and services 
(water supply and sanitation, waste management, other 
municipal services, urban sector development)  
Themes (subthemes)  –  Economic growth (promoting economic efficiency and enabling 
business environment), environmental sustainability (urban 
environmental improvement), capacity development (institutional 
development) 
Climate change  –  Adaptation and mitigation 
Location (impact)  –  Urban (high), national (medium), rural (low), regional (low) 
Partnerships  –  UN-HABITAT and others yet to be determined. 
 
NOTE 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars.

CONTENTS 
Page 
 
I.  INTRODUCTION  1 
II.  ISSUES  1 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE  2 
A.  Impact and Outcome  3 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities  3 
C.  Cost and Financing  4 
D.  Implementation Arrangements  4

APPENDIXES 
1.     Design and Monitoring Framework  6 
2.     Cost Estimates and Financing Plan  9 
3.     Outline Terms of Reference for Consultants  10

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Since  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB) resumed  operations  in  Myanmar  in  2012, 
strengthening and developing the capacities of sector institutions has been a priority before 
lending operations for urban development and water resume. ADB’s approach is to assist line 
ministries and other government entities with capacity development with the assumption that 
later  project  implementation  will  benefit  from  these  activities.1 This  capacity  development 
technical assistance (TA) was developed taking into account the newly emerging challenges 
and requirements of a rapidly transforming Myanmar. The proposal was discussed with the 
government during various consultation missions, and the government concurs with the impact, 
outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and terms of 
reference. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The opening of the economy in Myanmar will transform the country’s cities and the way 
they are managed. Till the recent government reforms, the government took the lead in urban 
development through the creation of large settlement areas with minimal infrastructure and 
services. In newly created ‘sites and services’ settlements, people were offered serviced plots 
where homes could be built. Other urban planning was characterized by supply-driven schemes 
representing the government’s priorities rather than economic, social or environmental needs. 
Cost recovery considerations in municipal finance did not feature prominently. The existing level 
of provision of essential environmental infrastructure and basic urban services, in particular for 
those living in informal settlements, is far below standards commonly found in Southeast Asia, 
and this results in significant risks to public health and increased infant and child morbidity and 
mortality. The six selected cities3 face emerging challenges to improve urban service provision 
and organize a sustainable development path. Hence, the training approach suggested for this 
TA is an action approach to develop business plans for key urban service sectors, i.e., water 
supply, sanitation, waste management, drainage, and flood management.   
 
3.  Myanmar  has  experienced  major  reforms  since  2010,  including  democratization, 
decentralization, and trade liberalization, and the country is expected to gradually integrate into 
regional and international trade networks and become increasingly involved in the international 
community. Therefore, it is timely to introduce modern urban management concepts that reflect 
agreed  priority  needs  and  the  government’s  socioeconomic  and  spatial  strategies,  and  to 
incorporate these concepts into the provision of essential services. Urban management will be 
expected  to  respond  constructively  and  proactively  to  Myanmar’s  changing  circumstances: 
greater demands will be placed on the efficient functioning of cities, their planned and balanced 
growth, and their ability to provide more equitable access to services. Myanmar therefore needs 
to manage and regulate urban growth through proactive planning of infrastructure and services 
and transparent land use and development control.  
 
4.  Governance. Myanmar shows weaknesses on governance according to most global 
governance indicators. The country’s public financial management system, which is central to 
                                                
1  The technical assistance (TA) deals with city-level capacity requirements. Other TA activities included under the 
proposed Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction (JFPR) grant for the Pro-Poor Community Infrastructure Development 
and Basic Services Project will be limited to four township administrations in Mandalay and Yangon only. The 
proposed capacity development TA for Myanmar Long-term Capacity Building for Civil Servants and Institutional 
Development will deal with more general civil servants reform issues only.  
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 24 June 2013.  
3  The six selected cities are Lashio, Mandalay, Mawlamyine, Monywa, Pathein, and Yangon.

2              
 
effective service delivery, is a case in point. Across government ministries and agencies, budget 
planning, transparency, execution, reporting, and accounting all have weaknesses. Evidence-
backed information on the Millennium Development Goals indicates that many dimensions of 
well-being  improved  between  2005  and  2010.  Nonetheless,  Myanmar  remains  one  of  the 
poorest countries in the world with a per capita gross domestic product of $860, a Human 
Development Index rank of 149 out of 187 countries, and 26% of its population living in poverty 
in 2010.4 Poverty incidence in rural areas is significantly higher than in urban areas, with 84% of 
the poor living in rural areas. Regional disparities in poverty incidence are large, and disparities 
in non-income forms of poverty exist across regions and population groups. A large segment of 
the  population  experiences  transitory  bouts  of  impoverishment  and  is  highly  vulnerable  to 
adverse weather and other shocks. Although local governments used to be considered the sole 
providers  of  urban  infrastructure  services,  under  the  new  market-driven  economy,  these 
services will increasingly need to respond to customer requirements and operate in a more 
profit-driven manner. ADB’s medium-term goal in  Myanmar is to assist the government in 
promoting  sustainable  and  inclusive  economic development  and  job  creation  in  support of 
poverty reduction. In the interim strategy period 2012‒2014, ADB will emphasize three program 
areas: (i) building human and institutional capacity in ADB’s areas of focus; (ii) promoting an 
enabling economic environment; and (iii) creating access and connectivity for rural livelihoods 
and  infrastructure  development.  ADB  will  mainstream  the  themes  of  (i)  environmental 
sustainability, (ii) good governance, (iii) private sector development, (iv) regional cooperation 
and integration, and (v) gender equality. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
5.  The TA will promote sustainable urban development in Myanmar cities by building the 
institutional capacity of local authorities, leading to the prioritized needs-based provision of 
essential  infrastructure.  This  capacity  development  activity  of  Part  I  (urban  management) 
prioritizes the development and effective management of six major cities (Batch I: Yangon, 
Mandalay, and Mawlamyine; Batch II: Pathein, Lashio, and Monywa), and further encourages 
the growth of district cities to stimulate balanced decentralized economic growth. Part II (flood 
management) will focus on three key cities only (Yangon, Mandalay, and Mawlamyine).5 The TA 
will develop the capacity of civil servants of local, regional, and government to plan, budget, and 
prepare for multisector urban development projects, some of which may eventually be funded 
by multilateral development banks, other development partners, or both. At the end of the TA, 
all six participating cities will have formulated business operations plans for key service sectors, 
i.e., water supply, sanitation, waste management, drainage, and flood management (Yangon, 
Mandalay  and  Mawlamyine  only,  since  they  face  increased  threat  from  flooding).6 These 
services represent relevant areas for possible future ADB investments. The business operations 
plans will cover aspects of technical operations, financial management, and inclusiveness of 
service provision, taking into account the needs and payment capacity of the urban poor. The 
TA will test its activities in Yangon before scaling them up to other towns.    
 
6.  The long-term outcome of the TA is an enhanced urban environment (and climate change 
resilience) of cities through urban and environmental infrastructure improvement and stronger 
urban management capacity. Planned urban growth, with improved urban infrastructure and 
                                                
4   Ministry  of  National  Planning  and  Economic  Development,  Swedish  International  Development  Cooperation 
Agency, United Nations Children’s Fund, United Nations Development Programme. 2011. Integrated Household 
Living Conditions Survey in Myanmar (2009–2010); ADB. 2012. Asian Development Outlook 2001: Update. Manila. 
5  Approximate  population  figures:  Yangon:  5  million;  Mandalay:  1.25  million;  Mawlamyine:  500,000;  Pathein: 
300,000, Lashio: 200,000; and Monywa: 300,000. 
6   If progress of the TA permits, part II (flood management) may also include Pathein, Lashio, and Monywa.

3 
services, will afford better opportunities to the urban poor and other marginalized communities 
to share in the expected benefits of Myanmar’s economic growth. This capacity development 
activity prioritizes the development and effective management of selected cities and encourages 
the growth of district cities to stimulate balanced decentralized economic growth. 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The expected impact of the TA is that urban management will become more effective 
and inclusive, reflecting new government policies on socioeconomic and spatially balanced 
development. The outcome of this TA will be improved skills of city authorities to manage urban 
development in a participatory and inclusive manner by formulating business operations plans 
for urban service sectors (i.e., water supply, sanitation, waste management, drainage, and flood 
management) through a “learning by doing” approach. Participating cities will also prepare 
guidelines for standards of urban services delivery covering water supply, sanitation, waste 
management, drainage, and flood management. In addition, the Ministry of Construction (MOC) 
and the Department of Meteorology and Hydrology will conduct a hydro-meteorological analysis 
in the Ayeyarwady River basin and the Yangon plain and produce guidelines and manuals for 
proper flood risk management.7 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  The TA will focus on capacity building for urban management approaches, including 
strategic urban planning and land management, development control procedures, preparation of 
urban  services  projects,  and  pro-poor  infrastructure,  which  may  be  implemented  through 
community-based mechanisms. Priority subsectors for intervention are water, sanitation, solid 
waste management, and flood control. Investment in Myanmar’s urban development is strongly 
justified since urban areas have greatly contributed to economic growth and poverty reduction. 
Cities are growing rapidly, yet their growth has been uneven and is often unplanned, and they 
remain  vulnerable  to  water-related  disasters,  such  as  floods  and  storm  surges.  Economic 
specialization is taking place in medium-sized urban areas, which are growing in importance. 
The urbanization trend is further strengthened by the market orientation of the economy and the 
regional policy of open borders, offering opportunities for Myanmar to benefit from its strategic 
geographic location and its inclusion in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations and the 
Greater Mekong Subregion.8 The concept of modernization and the transformation of urban 
management delineate new roles and responsibilities in urban development and management 
for the  central government, for  state  or regional  governments,  and for  local governments. 
Regulated  urban  planning  and  land  use  administration  will  promote  transparency  and 
democracy among urban local governments.  
 
9.  The tools and procedures required to introduce these concepts of urban management, 
which  form  part  of  the  public  administration  reform  program,  will  provide  opportunities  for 
innovative approaches to urban management and will help the MOC develop standards and 
guidelines. 
 
10.  A hydro-meteorological analysis related to floods and storm surges in the Ayeyarwady 
River basin and the Yangon plain will be conducted. This analysis will be incorporated into the 
urban services business operations plans in the participating cities. The capacity of specialists 
in related government organizations, such as the Department of Meteorology and Hydrology, 
                                                
7   Also known as the Irrawaddy River.  
8   The linkages between the People’s Republic of China, India, and Myanmar will require special attention and justify 
engagement in Lashio, to the northeast of Mandalay, and Monywa, to its northwest.

4              
 
will  be  developed  by  introducing  training  programs  and  incorporating  advanced  hydro-
meteorological analysis methods. 
 
11.  Expected outputs. There will be five major outputs: (i) community and capacity needs 
assessment  and  development  of training modules;  (ii)  implementation of  training  activities, 
testing of course materials, and implementation of core program; (iii) formulation of urban 
services business operations plans; (iv) institutional sustainability of capacity development; and 
(v) flood management.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $2,220,000, of which $2,000,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis  by  the  Japan  Fund  for  Poverty  Reduction  (JFPR)  and  administered  by  ADB.  The 
government  will  provide  counterpart  support  in  the form  of  counterpart  staff,  office  space, 
communication facilities for consultants, and other in-kind contributions. The cost and financing 
plan is in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  The MOC, through the Department of Human Settlements and Housing Development, will 
be the executing agency.9 The MOC is the main agency responsible for the planning and 
management of urban infrastructure and services. The Department of Human Settlements and 
Housing Development, which used to serve only the greater Yangon region, has become an 
entity of the MOC, and is now supposed to service the entire country. This expansion has 
placed major strains on the limited capacities of the department and the MOC. The proposed TA 
is  intended  to  improve  the  MOC’s  management  capacity  and  to  help  city  development 
committees to employ a “learning by doing” approach given their own capacity limitations. The 
executing agency will establish a multiagency steering committee consisting of representatives 
from the MOC, other ministries, professional organizations, and city development committees. 
The steering committee will supervise the work and outcome of the TA.  
 
14.  The  MOC,  through  the  Urban  Research  and  Development  Institute,  will  be  the 
implementing agency. The institute was established in January 2012 (with support from UN-
HABITAT) to strengthen policy formulation and arrange training programs to build national and 
local  government  capacities  in  inclusive  urban  planning  and  management.  The  institute  is 
currently providing training for newly recruited staff of the Yangon City Development Committee 
through  its  induction  program  of  in-service  training.  Part  II  will  be  developed  with  the 
Department of Meteorology and Hydrology, which provides weather forecasts, flood forecasts, 
and flood reduction measures. The department will also be involved in the subsector of drainage 
and flood management under Part I. 
 
15.  The TA will be implemented over 24 months from 1 January 2014 to 31 December 2015. 
TA proceeds will be disbursed in accordance with  the Technical Assistance Disbursement 
Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).10 The TA will finance an estimated 61.5 
person-months  of  international  consultants  and  70 person-months  of  national  consultants, 
covering both Part I and Part II. There will be one contract for Part I and two contracts for Part II.  
All consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time). Procurement under this TA will be in 
                                                
9  The MOC intends to assume a lead role in the development of regulatory guidelines for the urban water sector and 
for other urban services. Currently, there are many institutions involved in the oversight of rural water, while urban 
water still lacks a clear leader.  
10  Expenditures adhere to JFPR 2013 Policy Guidelines, specifically eligible expenditures and ineligible expenditures.

5 
accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2013, as amended from time to time). The 
procurement modality for Part I (urban management) will use quality- and cost-based selection, 
and  the  quality-cost  ratio  will  be  80:20.  Two  firms  will  be  recruited  under  Part  II  (flood 
management),  one  by  single  source  selection,  and  the  other  by  quality-  and  cost-based 
selection with a quality-cost ratio of 80:20. The International Centre for Water Hazard and Risk 
Management (ICHARM) will be hired by ADB through the single source selection method to 
provide their own methodology of hydro-meteorological analysis in the Ayeyarwady River basin 
and the Yangon plain as well as other countries’ lessons in better flood risk management. 11 
 
16.  The  selection  of  ICHARM  is  justified  by  the  exceptional  value  of  its  technological 
expertise and experience. ICHARM has developed  a proprietary and unique  rainfall runoff 
inundation  model,  which  can  reproduce  runoff  processes  in mountainous  areas  and rivers 
coupled with flood inundation phenomenon in flood plains. ICHARM’s model was employed with 
satellite-based hydrological data in a Japan International Cooperation Agency project, “Project 
on a Comprehensive Flood Management Plan for the Chao Phraya River Basin,” and was highly 
regarded for its valuable results in the analysis of the 2011 flood in Thailand. As a result of its 
application  to  the  Indus  River  basin  in  Pakistan  utilizing  satellite-based  hydrological  data, 
ICHARM’s  model  was  lauded  by  the  United  Nations  Educational,  Scientific  and  Cultural 
Organization for its usefulness in flood-inundation forecasting and management over the large-
scale river basin. There is a dearth of hydrological data, such as rainfall and elevation data, for 
the Ayeyarwady River basin (the target area of this project), which comprises a mountainous 
area and a vast delta. To estimate flood risk for the basin, a comprehensive approach covering 
river runoff processes from slopes to flood plains using satellite-based hydrological data must 
be  applied.  ICHARM  also  provides  master’s  and  doctoral  degrees  and  other  educational 
programs  for  international  students,  including  those  from  Myanmar.  ICHARM  is  the  only 
organization in the region that can effectively execute flood inundation analysis as well as 
capacity development in flood inundation analysis.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION 
 
17.  The  President  recommends  that  the  Board  approve  ADB  administering  technical 
assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $2,000,000 to the Government of Myanmar to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction for Transformation of Urban 
Management. 
 
                                                
11 ICHARM is a research center under the management of the Public Works Research Institute, Japan. It is the 
regional water knowledge hub for disaster risk reduction and flood management under the Knowledge Hubs 
initiative of the Asia-Pacific Water Forum.

Source: Asian Development Bank estimates.

10  Appendix 3 
 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
A.  General Requirements 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will be implemented over 24 months from 1 January 2014 
to 31 December 2015. The TA proceeds will be disbursed in accordance with the Technical 
Assistance  Disbursement  Handbook  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time)  of  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB).1 A team of international and national urban development experts will 
be engaged to implement the project. The TA will finance an estimated 61.5 person-months of 
international consultants and 70 person-months of national consultants, covering both Part I and 
Part II. There will be one contract for Part I and two contracts for Part II. All consultants will be 
engaged by ADB in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as 
amended from time to time), and procurement under this TA will be in accordance with ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines (2013, as amended from time to time). For Part II (flood management), 
two firms will be recruited, one by single source selection, and the other by quality- and cost-
based selection with a quality-cost ratio of 80:20. The International Centre for Water Hazard and 
Risk Management (ICHARM) will be hired by ADB through the single source selection method 
to provide: (i) their own methodology of hydro-meteorological analysis in the Ayeyarwady River 
basin  and  the  Yangon  plain,  and  (ii)  lessons  from  other  countries  for  better  flood  risk 
management.  
2.  The team of consultants under Part I will consist of two international experts (urban 
management expert and finance expert) and various national consultants. The team leader and 
deputy  team  leader  will  be  responsible  for  the  day-to-day  implementation  of  the  TA.  The 
consultants will carry out these tasks: 
(i)  manage and administer the day-to-day operations and implementation of the TA; 
(ii)  take the lead in networking activities with national and subnational organizations;  
(iii)  take the lead in policy dialogues related to the TA;  
(iv)  guide the activities of the training needs assessment and secure approval of the 
training course contents from the executing agency and ADB;  
(v)  plan, coordinate, manage, and evaluate training activities suitable for staff;  
(vi)  conduct periodic project reviews and evaluations, and assess the quality of all TA 
activities;  
(vii)  lead the formulation of the draft urban development strategy document;  
(viii)  provide  secretariat  services  and  technical  and  administrative  support  to  the 
interagency workshops and meetings related to the TA;  
(ix)  liaise with key development partners, national agencies, and other stakeholders; 
and  
(x)  prepare the necessary briefings and progress reports for ADB. 
 
B.  Specific Terms of Reference 
1.  Urban management (Part I) 
3.  Team leader and urban management expert (international, 18 person-months, full-
time). The expert will have at least 10 years of experience in urban management projects and 
capacity development activities with an advanced university degree (master’s or PhD) in urban 
management, urban and regional planning, or any similar field. The team leader will (i) monitor 
                                                
1  Expenditures  adhere  to  Japan  Fund  for  Poverty  Reduction  2013  Policy  Guidelines,  specifically  eligible 
expenditures and ineligible expenditures.

Appendix 3  11 
overall performance of the TA, (ii) lead the preparation of pilot capacity development and 
scaling-up  activities,  (iii)  lead  the  preparation  of  knowledge  products,  (iv)  lead  the 
institutionalization of the program, (v) review internal and external quality audit reports and 
recommend any necessary responses, and review all other reports as appropriate, (vi) review 
all technical and administrative reports, and (vii) lead coordination with the executing agency 
and major stakeholders.  
 
4.  Deputy team leader and civil engineer (national, 12 person-months, intermittent). The 
expert will have at least 10 years of experience in urban development projects and several 
years in capacity development activities, with a university degree in civil engineering. The 
deputy team leader will (i) assist the team leader in guiding the consultant team, (ii) assist the 
team leader in the preparation of pilot capacity development activities, (iii) assist the team 
leader  in  the  preparation  of  knowledge  products,  (iv)  assist  the  team  leader  in  the 
institutionalization of the program, (v) review internal and external quality audit reports and 
recommend any necessary responses, (vi) review all technical and administrative reports, and 
(vii) assist the team leader in communicating with the executing agency and major stakeholders. 
 
5.  Urban management and finance expert (international, 5 person-months, intermittent). 
The expert will have at least 10 years of experience in management and financing of urban 
development projects and several years in capacity development activities, with a university 
degree in urban finance, urban economics, or any similar field. The expert will (i) advise the 
team leader and guide the consultant team in conducting a training needs assessment and 
preparing curricula, (ii) advise the core team on implementation of management workshops and 
technical courses, (iii) advise the team leader on quality control of documents, (iv) advise the 
team leader on how to scale up the capacity development program, (v) advise the team leader 
on the preparation of the draft urban development strategy document (i.e., the urban code), and 
(vi) advise on the preparation of an institutionalization strategy for capacity development. 
 
6.  Procurement specialist (national, 6 person-months, intermittent). The expert will have 
at least 5 years of experience in procurement of urban development projects and several years 
in  capacity  development  activities,  with  a  university  degree  in  engineering,  management, 
administration, or any related field. The procurement specialist will assist the team leader and 
deputy team leader on the capacity-building and training on procurement-related aspects of 
urban and infrastructure management by providing inputs on the following: (i) training needs 
assessment;  (ii)  curricula  preparation;  (iii)  implementation  of  management  workshops  and 
technical courses; (iv) preparation of consolidated training materials; (v) quality control; and (vi) 
institutionalization of the program. 
 
7.  Social safeguards specialist (national, 6 person-months, intermittent). The expert will 
have  at  least  5  years  of  experience  in  social  safeguards  and  several  years  in  capacity 
development activities, with a university degree on community development, or any related field 
in the social sciences. The social safeguards specialist will assist the team leader or deputy 
team leader on matters relating to resettlement and land acquisition, indigenous peoples, and 
gender action planning for the following core tasks: (i) training needs assessment; (ii) curricula 
preparation;  (iii)  implementation  of  management  workshops  and  technical  courses;  (iv) 
preparation of consolidated training materials; (v) quality control; and (vi) institutionalization of 
the program. 
 
8.  Environment specialist (national, 6 person-months, intermittent). The expert will have 
at least 5 years of experience in environmental planning and safeguards of urban development 
projects  and  several  years  in  capacity  development  activities,  with  a  university  degree  in

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
environmental science, environmental management, environmental engineering, or any related 
field of study. The environment specialist will assist the team leader or deputy team leader on 
matters relating to the initial environmental examination, environmental analysis, and climate 
change adaptation for the following core tasks: (i) training needs assessment; (ii) curricula 
preparation;  (iii)  implementation  of  management  workshops  and  technical  courses;  (iv) 
preparation of consolidated training materials; (v) quality control; and (vi) institutionalization of 
the program. 
 
9.  Urban planner (national, 6 person-months, intermittent). The expert will have at least 5 
years of experience in urban development planning and several years in capacity development 
activities, with a university degree in urban and regional planning, town planning, or any similar 
field. The urban planner will assist the team leader and deputy team leader on matters relating 
to comprehensive land use planning for the following core tasks: (i) training needs assessment; 
(ii) curricula preparation; (iii) implementation of management workshops and technical courses; 
(iv) preparation of consolidated training materials; (v) quality control; and (vi) institutionalization 
of the program. 
 
10.  Five short-term experts, various disciplines (national, 10 person-months). Five short-
term experts will assist the team leader and deputy team leader in the following core tasks: (i) 
training  needs  assessment;  (ii)  curricula  preparation;  (iii)  implementation  of  management 
workshops and technical courses; (iv) preparation of consolidated training materials; (v) quality 
control; and (vi) institutionalization of the program. 
 
11.  Training  and  administrative  officer  (national,  24  person-months,  full-time).  The 
training officer will have at least 5 years of experience in project and training administration, with 
a university degree in administration, management, social sciences, or any related field. The 
consultant will do the following: (i) administer training events: (ii) coordinate travel arrangements 
in accordance with security and safety guidelines; (iii) control the register of official reports and 
provide reports as authorized; (iv) provide overall management of the communication systems, 
office supplies and services, office equipment, and backup of computer data; (v) manage the TA 
petty  cash,  payments,  acquittal,  and  replenishment;  (vi)  perform  internal  audits  on  the 
administrative quality systems; (vii) arrange annual external audits of accounts; (viii) identify 
ways to improve the overall administration services to the management team; (ix) assist the 
team leader in: (a) preparing consultant contracts; (b) preparing and distributing documents; (c) 
arranging  meetings  and  appointments;  (d)  controlling  confidential  documents;  (e)  providing 
secretariat functions to the interagency committee through record management, photocopying 
and binding, distribution of documents, and organization of board meetings; and (f) maintaining 
a library of photo documentation; (x) operate the project accounting system in accordance with 
the quality manual for financial management; (xi) prepare monthly and ad hoc financial reports; 
(xii) maintain the asset register; (xiii) prepare and issue checks based on approved procurement 
orders; (xiv) prepare and process payroll and other salary-related payments; (xv) maintain cash 
flow projections and request fund amounts appropriate for the next period; (xvi) assist in all audit 
operations; and (xvii) organize an account closure workshop for local government units with 
completed subprojects and those nearing completion in preparation for the closure of books of 
accounts. 
 
2.  Flood management (Part II) 
12.  Team  leader  and  flood  management  expert  (international,  2.25  person-months, 
intermittent).  The  team  leader  will  have  a  master’s  degree  or  higher  in  civil  engineering, 
hydrology, or any water-related engineering field, and more than 10 years of experience in

Appendix 3  13 
water-related disaster risk management and project management in Asia and the Pacific. The 
team leader will: (i) monitor overall performance of Part II (flood management); (ii) review all 
technical and administrative reports; (iii) lead coordination with the executing agency and major 
stakeholders; and (iv) maintain quality of the Part II work on flood management. 
 
13.  Hydrological  and  hydraulic  modeling  specialist  and  flood  and  storm  surge 
analysis  specialist  (international,  6.25  person-months,  intermittent).  The  hydrological  and 
hydraulic modeling specialist will have: (i) a master’s degree or higher in civil engineering, 
hydrology, or any water-related engineering; (ii) more than 5 years of experience in the field of 
hydrological and hydraulic modeling with earth observation satellite (EOS) data analysis of 
Global Satellite Mapping of Precipitation (GSMaP), Advanced Land Observing Satellite (ALOS), 
and  Moderate  Resolution  Imaging  Spectroradiometer  (MODIS);  and  (iii)  more  than  two 
appreciations of RRI simulation with EOS data in Asia and the Pacific. The specialist will: (i) 
prepare a list of necessary data and information for the RRI simulation in the Yangon plain, 
Ayeyarwady  River  basin  and  Thanlwin  River  basin,  including  satellite  information  such  as 
GSMaP, ALOS, and MODIS; (ii) supervise other consultant work collecting necessary data and 
information for the RRI simulation, including satellite information of GSMaP, ALOS, and MODIS; 
(iii) undertake field work  to understand the flood and storm surge situations in the Yangon plain, 
Ayeyarwady River basin, and Thanlwin River basin; (iv) conduct the RRI and storm surge 
simulation of the Yangon plain, Ayeyarwady River basin, and Thanlwin River basin using the 
collected data and information; (v) supervise training materials preparation on flood and storm 
surge risk assessment by Department of Meteorology and Hydrology staff; and (vi) supervise 
sub-consultants’ reports (inception report, interim report, draft final report, and final report). 
 
14.  Flood and storm surge risk assessment specialist (international, 6.25 person-months, 
intermittent). The flood and storm surge risk assessment specialist will have: (i) a master’s 
degree or higher in civil engineering, hydrology, or any water-related engineering field; (ii) more 
than 5 years of experience in water-related disaster risk management with EOS data analysis of 
GSMaP, ALOS, and MODIS; and (iii) more than one application of flood risk assessment in Asia 
and the Pacific. The flood and storm surge risk assessment specialist will: (i) prepare list of 
necessary data and information for the flood risk assessment in the Yangon plain, Ayeyarwady 
River  basin,  and  Thanlwin  River  basin;  (ii)  supervise  collection  of  necessary  data  and 
information for the flood risk assessment, including ALOS, GSMaP, and MODIS; (iii) undertake 
field  work  to  understand  the  flood  and  storm  surge  risk  situations  in  the  Yangon  plain, 
Ayeyarwady River basin, and Thanlwin River basin; (iv) supervise past hazard analysis and past 
disaster damage analysis as input to flood risk analysis; (v) supervise flood risk assessment in 
the Yangon plain, Ayeyarwady River basin, and Thanlwin River basin, including the methods to 
estimate housing damages and agricultural losses, preparation of flood and storm surge risk 
mapping, and estimation of damage cost from flood and storm surge; (vi) supervise preparation 
of training materials on flood and storm surge risk assessment by Department of Meteorology 
and Hydrology staff; and (vii) supervise preparation of sub-consultants’ reports. 
 
15.  Training  coordinator  (international,  3.75  person-months,  intermittent).  The  training 
coordinator  will  have:  (i)  a  university  degree  or  higher  in  engineering,  organizational 
development, management, or any related field; (ii) more than 2 years of experience in water-
related disaster risk management; and (iii) experience in capacity development in Asia and the 
Pacific. The training coordinator will (i) supervise a sub-consultant on planning of overall training 
activities  and  make  appropriate  suggestions;  (ii)  coordinate  with  the  Part  I  consultants 
concerning training programs and materials; (iii) supervise training of flood and storm surge risk 
assessment; and (iv) supervise preparation of sub-consultants’ reports.

14  Appendix 3 
 
 
Sub-consultant’s terms of reference. The consultant firm will work closely with ICHARM. Its 
services will be hired by ADB.  
 
16.  Coordinator  and  flood  management  expert  (international,  6.75  person-months, 
intermittent). The coordinator will have (i) a master’s degree or higher in civil engineering, 
hydrology, or any water-related engineering field; (ii) more than 10 years of experience in the 
water-related disaster risk management and project management in Asia and the Pacific; and 
(iii) experience of working with ICHARM. The coordinator will (i) lead the sub-consultant team to 
support the activities of ICHARM; (ii) collect the necessary data and information for the hazard 
analysis and damage analysis, estimates of damages (infrastructure; housing; and agriculture); 
(iii) verify the collected data and information for the hazard analysis and damage analysis 
(infrastructure; housing; and agriculture); (iv) support ADB and ICHARM to prepare reports and 
training materials.  
 
17.  Hydrological  and  hydraulic  modeling  engineer (international,  6.5  person-months, 
intermittent). The hydrological and hydraulic modeling engineer will have (i) a master’s degree 
or higher in civil engineering, hydrology, or any water-related engineering field; (ii) more than 3 
years of experience in hydrological and hydraulic modeling with EOS data analysis of GSMaP, 
ALOS, and MODIS; and (iii) experience in hydrological and hydraulic modeling, including use of 
the RRI model. The hydrological and hydraulic modeling engineer will (i) verify the collected 
data for the RRI simulation, (ii) support the establishment and validation of the RRI model in the 
basins of the Ayeyarwady, Thanlwin, and other allied rivers under the supervision of ICHARM, 
(iii) support the establishment and validation of RRI model in Ayeyarwady, Thanlwin, and other 
allied rivers, and (iv) prepare reports and training materials.  
 
18.  Satellite  information  engineer  (international,  3  person-months,  intermittent).  The 
satellite  information  engineer  will  have  a  master’s  degree  or  higher  in  civil  or  geodetic 
engineering, surveying, geography, hydrology, or any related field and more than 3 years of 
experience in the field of EOS data analysis, such as GSMaP, MODIS, and ALOS. The satellite 
information engineer will (i) collect satellite information such as ALOS, GSMaP, and MODIS for 
the RRI simulation and flood risk assessment, (ii) verify the collected data for the RRI simulation 
and risk assessment, and (iii) prepare reports and training materials.  
 
19.  Training expert (international, 3.75 person-months, intermittent). The training expert will 
have a master’s degree or higher in engineering, organizational development, management or 
any related field; more than 2 years experiences in the field of water-related DRM; and more 
than 2 years of experience in capacity development or training in Asia and the Pacific. The 
training expert will make logistical arrangements for the trainings on flood and storm surge risk 
assessment, and prepare reports and training materials.

metadata.Author: Asian Development Bank
metadata.Creator: Microsoft® Word 2010
metadata.Keywords: adb projects, urban management, urban transformation, myanmar, union of myanmar, adb technical assistance, capacity development technical assistance, cdta, tar
metadata.Subject: This technical assistance report is a decision document for the Transformation of Urban Management in Myanmar containing issues, impacts, outcomes, methodology and key activities as well as cost and financing and implementation arrangements presented to ADB’s Board of Directors or Management for approval.
metadata.Title: Transformation of Urban Management: Technical Assistance Report

author_page:
CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 15 August 2013) 
 
Currency unit  –  kyat (MK) 
MK1.00  =  $0.001027 
$1.00  =  MK973.57 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  ALOS  –  Advanced Land Observing Satellite 
  EOS  –  earth observation satellite 
  GSMaP  –  Global Satellite Mapping of Precipitation 
  ICHARM  –  International Centre for Water Hazard and Risk Management 
  JFPR  –  Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction 
  MOC  –  Ministry of Construction 
  MODIS  –  Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
  RRI  –  rainfall runoff inundation 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Capacity development technical assistance (CDTA) 
Targeting classification  –  General intervention 
Sector (subsectors)  –  Water supply and other municipal infrastructure and services 
(water supply and sanitation, waste management, other 
municipal services, urban sector development)  
Themes (subthemes)  –  Economic growth (promoting economic efficiency and enabling 
business environment), environmental sustainability (urban 
environmental improvement), capacity development (institutional 
development) 
Climate change  –  Adaptation and mitigation 
Location (impact)  –  Urban (high), national (medium), rural (low), regional (low) 
Partnerships  –  UN-HABITAT and others yet to be determined. 
 
NOTE 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars.  
 
Vice-President  S. Groff, Operations 2 
Director General  J. Nugent, Southeast Asia Department (SERD) 
Director  A. Leung, Urban Development and Water Division, SERD 
   
Team leader  F. Steinberg, Senior Urban Development Specialist, SERD 
Team members  L. Adams, Social Development Specialist, SERD  
A. Garrovillas, Associate Project Officer, SERD 
E. Honda, Principal Portfolio Management Specialist, SERD 
S. Kotagiri, Social Development Specialist (Resettlement), SERD 
S. Sandhu, Senior Environment Specialist, SERD  
S. Schapero, Senior Finance Specialist, SERD 
T. Sugiura, Water Resources Specialist, Regional and Sustainable 
Development Department
